article.text: Shelling continues as UN monitors arrive in Syria Birthplace of Syrian revolution is pounded Six killed in Syria protests as death toll climbs to 3,000 Gulfsands seeks alternative to troubled Syria Syrian troops resume shelling of residential areas Mum, Dad, friend who popped round for coffee randomly but I invited in anyway...this is Terry. And t... Drought in the Sahel region of West Africa is fast becoming a humanitarian crisis; Henry Makiwa trav... Pasty taxes. Granny taxes. Petrol cans. Queues at the pump. Chaotic NHS ‘reforms’. A looming debacle... yrian activists say regime forces fired on a funeral procession in the presence of UN observers, causing many casualties. The activists said the observers were not among the wounded today, but their vehicles were damaged. A UN spokesman confirmed the observers were caught up in the country's violence on Tuesday and their cars sustained damage. But Ahmad Fawzi, a spokesman for special envoy Kofi Annan, had no other details. An Idlib-based activist, Fadi al-Yassin, said he witnessed the attack on the funeral and saw that the observers were there. The Britain-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights, citing a network of sources on the ground, also reported the attack.
